newsitem.title: USA: Dlr ends mostly up in US, jobs point to rate rise.
newsitem.headline: Dlr ends mostly up in US, jobs point to rate rise.

text.p: *Dlr ends up vs mark and Swiss franc, flat vs yen. Late sales of dollar/yen boost yen vs mark, drag dollar/mark off highs. *Stronger-than-expected August U.S. jobs data, broad mark sell-off and rallies in U.S. stocks and bonds buoy dollar. *But dollar faces tough resistance at 109.50 yen, 1.4960 marks. *Mark/Paris, most other mark/European crosses also lower.
The U.S. unit rose after the release of August U.S. jobs data, led by gains in dollar/Swiss.

The dollar climbed as high as 1.4935 marks, 1.2200 Swiss francs and 109.42 yen before a late round of selling in dollar/yen triggered stops in mark/yen at 73.20, pressuring the U.S. currency to close off its highs, traders said.
"It was a very thin Friday afternoon market and it just drifted lower," said Peter Wadkins, vice president at Standard Chartered Bank.
The dollar ended at 1.4920/30 marks and 1.2185/95 Swiss francs against openings of 1.4848/53 and 1.2052/59.
The U.S. currency ended little changed against the yen at 109.15/18 compared with 109.17/22.

Long-awaited U.S. employment data for August showed the economy expanding at a brisk pace and increased the odds the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates this month, giving the dollar an early boost, analysts said.
"What you've got here is a pretty strong bias for a rate hike right now," said Kevin Harris, international economist at MCM CurrencyWatch.
The Labor Department reported the economy created 250,000 non-farm jobs in August aganist a revised 228,000 in July.
The jobless rate slumped to a seven-year low of 5.1 percent from a previous 5.4 percent, the government reported.
Economists on average had expected non-farm payrolls to rise by 224,000 in August, and the unemployment rate to edge lower to 5.3 percent.
"The (jobs) numbers lead us to think that the Federal Reserve will move in September, raising rates by 25 basis points," said Phoenix said.
Despite the good news on the interest rate front, many expect the dollar to have a difficult time surmounting resistance at 109.50 yen and 1.4960 marks next week.
"I can't see 110 dollar/yen next week. There's a lot of pressure on the topside for dollar/yen approaching the Japanese fiscal half-year (on September 30)," Wadkins said.
The mark was again broadly sold, against the yen and against European currencies.
Mark/yen closed at 73.13 after opening at 73.48.
Late in the day, mark/French franc was trading around 3.4146/50 compared with 3.4190/95 near the opening.
"The market seemed to be a little long of marks going into the end of the week. That precipitated a lot of selling of marks on the crosses," said Harris at MCM CurrencyWatch.
In other trade, sterling finished down at $1.5590/00 compared with $1.5656/63.
The dollar was Canadian $1.3732/37, up from C$1.3710/15.
The Australian dollar was $0.7990/95.
-- Daniel Rosenblum, 212-8559-1662
